article: Before I spoke to his school, Matt was waiting for me. He sat in his wheelchair _ to move. As soon as he saw me, he started _ . He could not talk, _ his laugh melted the hearts of everyone walking by. One of the teachers told me he was actually very smart. He just lost _ of his muscles due to a childhood disease. He was _ and very popular at his school -- his parents' love and encouragement made all the difference. On the contrary , at a book signing session, I met a girl _ the name of Anne. She walked up with her mom with a _ smile. Anne asked about my book with difficulty in her speech 9 _ a slight head-injury. I told her about it and she smiled the whole time and asked me to _ one for her. I did. Five minutes later, I heard a voice from Anne's father, "You know you will not understand the book. You can't _ well." He said it so _ that people were staring in their direction. Her confidence was ly _ and her bright smile was now replaced with a _ of total disappointment. He _ the book from her, brought it back to me and asked me to take it back. I asked him if he would allow me to buy the book for Anne. He said no with a _ response. I thought back to Matt. He could not speak, walk, or play but was actually very happy and _ doing well in school because of the love and _ of his parents. Anne, on the other hand, had a slight _ problem and may never know happiness or success because of a cold-hearted father. The truth is that whatever you are telling your _ makes the difference between their success and failure in life.
